p: Historically, HCoVs were largely considered to be relatively low virulence viruses that produced less severe, self-limiting disease, and were predominantly known as the second most prevalent cause of colds and upper respiratory infections (URIs), after rhinoviruses [ 2, 29]. The endemic human CoVs that cumulatively account for about 10â€“30% of URIs are HCoV-229E and HCoV-NL63, which are both alphacoronaviruses, and HCoV-OC43 and HCoV-HKU1, which are both betacoronaviruses [ 2]. Among patients with URIs severe enough to warrant hospitalization, one study found that approximately 5% of cases were attributable to rhinoviruses or HCoVs, but a substantial proportion of these hospitalized patients had underlying pulmonary or cardiac comorbidities that may have exacerbated their conditions [ 29].
